SEC-SCH-002 NEOM Operational Site Security of Uncontrolled once printed NEOM – Operational Site Security GENERAL 1.0 PURPOSE The purpose of this document is to clearly define the responsibilities for the security of sites that have been brought into an operational state across the NEOM region. Operational refers to a site that is no longer under construction. This includes all aspects of site security, including: • Operating a secure site or building complex. • Controlling access and maintaining identity management. • Loss prevention, excluding people’s personal items that are not explicitly under the protection of the security provider. • Protection of staff, visitors and other personnel. • Physical protection of data. • Protection of the reputation of the site function, owner and NEOM. If the site is still under construction, or has not been formally handed over, then the security requirements under Schedule S – Construction should still be applied. 2.0 DEFINITIONS The document uses three distinct organisations: • NEOM – Refers to the client organisation, their divisions and their duties in relation to construction security. • OPERATOR (NEOM, PROPONENT OR OWNER) – Refers to the organisation or company that utilises the site for its intended primary function, or the management organisation for the site. This entity may be part of NEOM or a private organisation appointed by NEOM. • SECURITY SUPPLIER – Refers to the security provider employed by the OPERATOR (NEOM, PROPONENT OR OWNER), or in certain cases, NEOM, to provide security of the site and its associated activities. 3.0 APPLICABILITY This document, and its requirements, apply to all operational sites that are operated within NEOM, or on behalf of NEOM. The exception to this is only where NEOM Security Department (NEOM PUBLIC SAFETY - SECURITY have granted a waiver to this Standard because the site needs to operate at a higher security level. This may be the case with some sites in their end state operation, or where the site is designated Critical Regional Infrastructure (CRI). 4.0 SCOPE The scope of this document covers all operational sites and related activity undertaken by the OPERATOR (NEOM,PROPONENT OR OWNER). The document sets the minimum standards that are mandatory for the safe and secure operation of the site within NEOM. The aim of the mandatory minimum standards is to: • Set minimum standards to meet the general security threat situation in NEOM. • Provide a consistent approach to security within NEOM avoiding areas of increased vulnerability. SEC-SCH-002 NEOM Operational Site Security of Uncontrolled once printed NEOM – Operational Site Security 5.0 RESPONSIBILITIES NEOM are responsible for overall regional security and over-seeing the secure operation of sites within the NEOM region and also the regulation of private security within the NEOM region. The OPERATOR (NEOM, PROPONENT OR OWNER) is responsible to NEOM for the security of the operational site, their operations within NEOM and wider KSA related to the site, supply chain, administration and supporting corporate offices. This includes activities that may have a potentially negative effect on the reputation of NEOM. The OPERATOR (NEOM,PROPONENT OR OWNER) shall provide 24 hours-a-day, 7 days-a-week, 365 days-a-year (24/7/365) security to mitigate the identified security risks. Risk is a dynamic element, and the OPERATOR (NEOM,PROPONENT OR OWNER) should plan to review their related security risk: • On a periodic basis. • After an incident or near miss event. • If advised to do so by NEOM PUBLIC SAFETY - SECURITY • Making the necessary adjustments if the threat level has increased. Security measures should never be reduced beyond the relevant minimum level for the category of the site, as this is likely to reduce the deterrent effect achieved. To achieve the security requirements, the OPERATOR (NEOM, PROPONENT OR OWNER) must either provide a suitably qualified in-house professional security capability or employ a suitably qualified and resourced SECURITY SUPPLIER. [Referred to hereafter as the SECURITY SUPPLIER.] The SECURITY SUPPLIER must provide sufficient professional security personnel who are suitably trained and equipped, in conjunction with infrastructure provided at the operational site to meet the security requirements mandated by NEOM PUBLIC SAFETY - SECURITY / NEOC & NEOM EMERGENCY OPERATIONS CENTRE (NEOC) through the Operational Site Security Standard. SECURITY PROCESS 6.0 PROCESS The following process will be followed by all OPERATOR (NEOM,PROPONENT OR OWNER(S)) and their SECURITY SUPPLIERS to evidence their compliance with the mandatory security requirements of NEOM operational sites. Compliance will not be a ‘one-off’ event and NEOM PUBLIC SAFETY - SECURITY / NEOM EMERGENCY OPERATIONS CENTRE (NEOC) will audit the site security to ensure the minimum requirements are being met. SEC-SCH-002 NEOM Operational Site Security of Uncontrolled once printed NEOM – Operational Site Security 6.1 Site Suitability Assessment The Site Suitability Assessment (SSA) is undertaken to confirm that adequate security measures will be in place once the operational security overlay is applied. It should review the infrastructure, which should have been designed to meet the requirements for security and safety at the site, and it is therefore expected that minimal to no changes will be required. This form of a familiarisation visit will help both OPERATOR (NEOM,PROPONENT OR OWNER) and SECURITY SUPPLIER develop their Security Management Plan and Site Security Instructions, and identify those elements of non-fixed security infrastructure and resourcing to be provided under their contract. This may include radio systems, mobile duress alarms, search mirrors etc. A short report should be produced following the visit and submitted to NEOM PUBLIC SAFETY - SECURITY / NEOC & NEOM EMERGENCY OPERATIONS CENTRE (NEOC) for review and discussion. 7.0 SITE CATEGORISATION Every site within NEOM has been categorised using pre-defined criteria to establish the security risk level to the site and a corresponding Security Tier Level (STL). The STL sets the minimum or baseline security infrastructure standards that must be incorporated into the design of the site to meet the assessed threat in combination with: • An Operational Security Overlay: A Concept of Security Operations will be provided based upon the site design to provide an outline of the operational planning and activities envisioned for the site. The OPERATOR (NEOM, PROPONENT OR OWNER) is responsible for developing this information into the operational security employer requirements on which the contract with the SECURITY SUPPLIER will be based. • Site Security Procedures and Instructions: The OPERATOR (NEOM, PROPONENT OR OWNER) and SECURITY SUPPLIER are responsible for developing the correct level of procedures and instructions for the site, and these will form the basis of the Security Management Plan (Section 8) and the Site Security Instructions (Section 9). It is essential that the security infrastructure is operated and maintained correctly so that it has the desired security effect. Guidance around this is provided in Section 11 – Site Security Infrastructure and Section 12 – Identity Management and Access Control. 8.0 SECURITY MANAGEMENT PLAN The Security Management Plan (SMP) is the responsibility of the OPERATOR (NEOM,PROPONENT OR OWNER). The SMP should be produced a minimum of 12 weeks prior to the site moving to an operational status. The SMP provides a description of how the OPERATOR (NEOM,PROPONENT OR OWNER) will meet its security responsibilities. The minimum requirements of the SMP are detailed in Appendix A. The SMP shall be submitted to NEOM PUBLIC SAFETY - SECURITY / NEOC & NEOM EMERGENCY OPERATIONS CENTRE (NEOC) as evidence of adequate security planning having been Rev No: 0. SEC-SCH-002 NEOM Operational Site Security of Uncontrolled once printed NEOM – Operational Site Security undertaken. This includes the completion of the SMP Compliance Checklist, which is included at Appendix B to this document and the Security Overlays in Appendix C. As the SMP is the OPERATOR (NEOM,PROPONENT OR OWNER)’s responsibility, the Site Security Manager shall be a member of the OPERATOR (NEOM,PROPONENT OR OWNER)’s employed staff to ensure that the SMP is correctly interpreted and applied to the site. The SMP should evidence the capabilities of the site security infrastructure to allow the SMP to be further developed in sufficient detail with an intimate understanding of the site. To do this, a series of security overlays shall be prepared during the SMP stage. The required minimum overlays are as follows: • Privacy Zoning. • Access Control Overlay and Control Lines. • Dynamic Lockdown Procedure. • Surveillance Overlay Trace. • Intruder Detection Zones. • Search Difficulty Trace. • Evacuation and Invacuation Routes. • Emergency Red Routes. • Muster points. • Incident Control Points, Media Holding Area and Incident Vehicle Control Points. The overlays should be used operationally and incorporated into Security Control Room information and the information used during security activity and incidents. Examples are provided in Appendix C. It should be noted that the SMP is an auditable document. 9.0 SITE SECURITY INSTRUCTION The Site Security Instruction (SSI) is the responsibility of the SECURITY SUPPLIER, to meet the requirements of the OPERATOR (NEOM,PROPONENT OR OWNER)’s SMP. The SSI defines the procedures and assignment instructions that the SECURITY SUPPLIER will undertake on behalf of the OPERATOR (NEOM,PROPONENT OR OWNER) to achieve a safe and secure operational site. An SSI is required for all operational sites regardless of size and complexity. The fully completed SSI must be submitted a minimum of 4 weeks prior to any site being occupied. The minimum requirements of the SSI are detailed in Appendix D. The SSI Compliance Checklist is included at Appendix E. It should be noted that the SSI and its associated contents are auditable documents. Rev No: 0. SEC-SCH-002 NEOM Operational Site Security of Uncontrolled once printed NEOM – Operational Site Security 10.0 REPORTING REQUIREMENTS NEOM PUBLIC SAFETY - SECURITY / NEOC & NEOM EMERGENCY OPERATIONS CENTRE (NEOC) expects that the OPERATOR (NEOM,PROPONENT OR OWNER) and SECURITY SUPPLIER are responsible for the day-to-day application of security at the site under the leadership of the Site Security Manager. However, it is beneficial for certain events, occurrences and incidents to be reported to NEOM PUBLIC SAFETY - SECURITY / NEOC & NEOM EMERGENCY OPERATIONS CENTRE (NEOC). Therefore, the reporting requirements to NEOM PUBLIC SAFETY - SECURITY / NEOC & NEOM EMERGENCY OPERATIONS CENTRE (NEOC) are for the following three categories: • Management Information. • Information of Suspicious Nature. • Reportable Incidents. Report and Log formats have been standardised to keep consistency of reporting and reference the same across all operational sites. These can be found at Appendix F. 10.1 Management Information The OPERATOR (NEOM,PROPONENT OR OWNER), through the Site Security Manager, is responsible for ensuring the following management information is provided to the OPERATOR (NEOM,PROPONENT OR OWNER) and NEOM PUBLIC SAFETY - SECURITY / NEOC & NEOM EMERGENCY OPERATIONS CENTRE (NEOC), as indicated: Daily: • Reportable Incidents as defined in sub-section 11.3. A Nil Incidents to Report is not required and it will be assumed the absence of a report indicates this. • A Security Daily Activity Log shall be maintained as a complete diary of security activity, events and incidents on the site. These logs must be archived once full for a minimum period of two full calendar years, or longer if specified by local Police regulations, from the last dated entry. Weekly: • Dropped Security Shifts indicating the manpower shortfall and over what periods. • Planned duties/checks that did not occur in the week and the remedial plan to rectify. • Collated ‘Suspicious Activity’ Report. • Complaints registered against security staff, regardless of the outcome. • Occurrences that involve an external agency or government department. Monthly: • Review of site security including Site Security Manager and OPERATOR (NEOM,PROPONENT OR OWNER) management comments. • Incident data for the preceding month. See report formats included at Appendix F. Rev No: 0. This information will be assessed by the Site Security Manager and any appropriate investigation will be undertaken. Posters, computer banners and other highly viewed media should contain the NEOC number and details around caller confidentiality. A sample poster format is provided below. All of the above Reportable Incidents must use the report format included at Attachment 1 to this document. 11.0 SITE SECURITY INFRASTRUCTURE The site has been designed and constructed with site security infrastructure based upon the STL assigned to the site. It is imperative that this infrastructure is used effectively and that it is maintained to the highest standard to deliver its required security effect. The following sub- sections define activities that are mandatory for the types of infrastructure and the OPERATOR (NEOM,PROPONENT OR OWNER) and SECURITY SUPPLIER must ensure these are included in the relevant sections of the SMP and SSI. These activities will be audited. 11.1 Perimeter Fence, Wall or Boundary Barriers The site perimeter for any site is a vital barrier to entry, or important demarcation line for the rules and regulations of the site to be enforced. Therefore, there are activities that must be completed by the SECURITY SUPPLIER to ensure the correct level of security is maintained. 11.1.1 Physically Barriered Perimeters The following requirements to maintain security of the site shall be met: • During patrols security staff will ensure that sections of the perimeter are visually inspected for: o Damage to the fabric of the barrier. o Signs of climbing of the barrier from outside or inside. o Ensuring that climbing aids are not left against the barrier or with a horizontal distance of 2.0m of the barrier on either side. o Ensuring vehicles are not being parked against the barrier. Where this is occurring, this should be reported for maintenance and repair. • The patrol planning should take into account perimeter checks and also ensure over a weekly period that all areas of the perimeter are visited at least once physically. • Patrol patterns should not be pattern setting. • Observation should be made to identify areas of the perimeter where increased activity has taken place. This should be reported and placed onto the Security Control Room ‘Area-Watchlist’. • Checks should be completed at different times of the day, including dark hours and weekends. • If a breach in the barrier is discovered it should be reported immediately and security staff should remain at the breach until effective repairs have been completed, where a secure perimeter has been installed. • Patrols should assess lighting at the perimeter and report any damaged or partially operating lighting to facilities management for maintenance and repair. 11.1.2 Non-Physically Barriered Perimeters The following requirements to maintain security of the site shall be met: • Patrols should be tasked along the perimeter line of the site and pay particular attention to transition points on and off the site. • Patrols should check that any signage at the perimeter is secure and has not become unreadable or defaced. • Particular attention should be paid to areas where evidence of entry or exit has occurred that is not along a desired movement corridor. This should be reported to the SCR and placed upon the Security Control Room ‘Area Watchlist’. • Patrols should look for acts of anti-social behaviour, gatherings etc that will affect the reputation of the site. Where this is occurring then this should be discussed with the Site Security Manager to plan a long-term approach to prevention. • Patrols should assess lighting at the perimeter and report any damaged or partially operating lighting to facilities management for maintenance and repair. 11.2 Video Surveillance System To support the physical site perimeter and operational overlay, video cameras may have been installed to provide coverage of the perimeter line and access points into the site. It is assumed that each site will have a dedicated location within either the Guard Post or a dedicated Security Control Room to pro-actively manage the camera coverage. Advice and requirements for VSS/CCTV please contact NEOM Public Safety - Security Director for Command and Control prior to your RFP procurement request. The Visual Surveillance System (VSS/CCTV) should be used to: • Provide strong situational awareness across the site to support operational security. • Provide a verification method for any intrusion alarms. OPERATOR (NEOM, Proponent or Owner(s)) need to be fully trained and compliant with any local regulations. The system must be reviewed regularly to ensure cameras are providing the images and image quality expected of the system. The SECURITY SUPPLIER is expected in conjunction with the OPERATOR (NEOM,PROPONENT OR OWNER) to ensure regular cleaning is undertaken in-line with any maintenance agreement. 11.3 Security Lighting and other External Illumination All security lighting and external lighting that aids safety and security should be inspected on a regular basis to ensure it is functional, undamaged and providing the required illumination. Where this is not the case, this should be reported to facilities management for maintenance and repair. Security staff should ensure that torches, hand-held or temporary illumination devices are serviceable and fully charged prior to dark hours shifts so that sufficient resilience and redundancy is present should a failure in fixed illumination occur. This is especially important at entry/exit points on the site. Dirty lights should be reported to facilities management for maintenance. Patrols must operate in safe lighting conditions but beyond strongly lit areas to be able to provide observation of less well lit areas. Night-time patrol planning should take account of this requirement to ensure that all areas of the site are adequately patrolled. 11.4 Security Guard Posts Security Guard Posts will be fixed infrastructure at the main ingress / egress point(s), to monitor and control movement onto and off site. These locations will serve as the Vehicle Access Control Points and Pedestrian Access Control Points for the site and are therefore vital to maintaining the required security level for the site. The Security Guard Posts are to be maintained and operated to the highest standards as these form the first impression that users and visitors of the site form about the professionalism and effectiveness of both site security, but also the wider site operations standard. A key element of the perception of the Security Guard Post will be formed on the following factors: • Cleanliness and neatness of the area. Rev No: 0. SEC-SCH-002 NEOM Operational Site Security of Uncontrolled once printed NEOM – Operational Site Security • Proactive, friendly and helpful interaction with security staff. • Robust, but polite removal of unauthorised people and vehicles. • Serviceability of all infrastructure in the area, especially elements such as shade cover, lighting etc that are very visual elements. • Timely processing of visitors to the right location with the right information and guidance. Staff attitude is key, and a concierge approach should be adopted. Site entry/exit procedures and the Security Guard Posts will be a principal focus of audits and also should correspondingly serve as an important measure of user satisfaction with security services. 11.5 Radio and Cellular Security Communications The SECURITY SUPPLIER will be responsible for the operation and maintenance of a site wide radio system for security personnel. The radio system must provide full coverage of the site, but is not required for communication to NEOM PUBLIC SAFETY - SECURITY / NEOC & NEOM EMERGENCY OPERATIONS CENTRE (NEOC). It is however, expected that the SECURITY SUPPLIER will also operate and maintain cellular phones for contact beyond the site boundaries. Communication equipment can be either supplied by the OPERATOR (NEOM,PROPONENT OR OWNER) or SECURITY SUPPLIER. The following requirements must be met: • A radio communications system connecting all security personnel including static points and also mobile patrols. • The system must be able to operate over a number of channels, providing for at least: o A core channel for day to day operations as the standard communications channel. o A minimum of two minor-incident channels to allow for separation of communication whilst still being able to operate the standard core channel. o One emergency channel is to be designated as the first-use channel for any incident. This will assist the fire and first aid responders to be ready for the incident as early as possible, but avoid the daily security ‘chatter’ of the standard daily channel. o A major emergency channel, reserved for usage under the authorisation of the Site Security Manager. o A management channel. • Enough radio communications equipment to ensure each member of staff on shift has a radio and enough spare batteries, spare parts and charging points. • One radio, spare battery and charger to be provided to the site fire control room or site fire officer for response requirements. Part of the security supervisor’s daily checks is to ensure that radios are charged and set to the correct first-use emergency channel. • Two radios, spare batteries and chargers are to be provided to the site first aid clinic. Part of the security supervisor’s daily checks is to ensure that radios are charged and set to the correct first-use emergency channel. • Information security should be maintained through correct usage of the radio system and sensitive information should not be passed over the radio unless completely necessary, or as part of an emergency situation. • OPERATOR (NEOM, Proponent or Owner(s)) should be trained that conversations can be overheard by those close to them, and as standard all OPERATOR (NEOM, Proponent or Owner(s)) should be issued with a single ear piece to help prevent eavesdropping. Radios should not be over-loud to disturb users of the site unnecessarily. • The site should demonstrate that if the radio system fails, that they have sufficient Rev No: 0. This should include the evidence of pre-programmed phone numbers etc, if the back-up if a fixed or cellular phone option. 11.6 Emergency Routes The site will have a number of established emergency routes. These routes should be treated as ‘Red Routes’ or routes that should not be blocked, congested or compromised in any way, as they represent the key firefighting routes, incident management or medical evacuation routes. Therefore, the following requirements should be met: • Only authorised vehicle parking spaces should be used. Unauthorised vehicle parking should be prevented. • Routes should be kept clear for the unhindered passage of 4.0m in width. • In an emergency these routes should be patrolled and controlled by security staff equipped with radio systems, and traffic control equipment. • Routes should be checked as part of mobile patrols regularly and on a continuous basis, including during dark hours. • A reference map of these routes should be kept in all guard posts and the SCR at all times. ‘Rip-off’ sheets of the map or copies should be kept to allow quick issue to emergency responders as required. • Users of the site should be made aware of restrictions for vehicle parking and other obstructions on these routes and the reason why. Alongside this should be an awareness briefing of valid parking spaces around the site, off-loading points and the procedures for needing to obstruct a Red Route. • An assessment procedure should be developed by the Site Security Manager for requests to obstruct a Red Route, so security shifts can be made aware of this, its duration and the alternative Red Routes that should be used during this period. • Red Routes should be developed in consultation with the Site Fire Officer. 11.7 Mass Notification The ability to provide mass notification or mass messaging should be designed into the infrastructure for the site to satisfy both fire and security regulations. The NEOC should be the single point of contact to coordinate all mass notifications at NEOM sites. It is recommended that the adoption of a cellular phone solution is also adopted to allow mass notification to regular site users and registered visitors via a SMS message should there be reasons not to attend the site. This would need to be completed by the NEOM digital presence that each individual has, and it is therefore recognised should include all registered users, residents and digital nomads. A similar system using computer monitor active banners should also be considered for a similar notification purpose, and also so security and other messages, that are not of immediate importance, can be reinforced across site users. Dependent on the type and severity of emergency situation that emerges OPERATOR (NEOM,PROPONENT OR OWNER(S)) should also consider, in consultation with NEOM, the use of local media such as television or radio broadcasting stations to promulgate mass notification messages if the incident covers a large area and requires the restriction of vehicles or people passing the area. SEC-SCH-002 NEOM Operational Site Security of Uncontrolled once printed NEOM – Operational Site Security 11.8 Muster Points Muster points for users of the site must be established, and site users must be made aware of the relevant muster point to them. Again, this activity should be coordinated with the Site Fire Officer. The muster points and their use have the following requirements: • Provide sufficient space for the site occupancy levels. • Provide sufficient space away from potential sources of vulnerability or threat. • Security staff should be dispatched to muster points as quickly as possible and should complete a visual search of the muster point to ensure it is safe for use. • Be usable during both daylight and dark hours safely. • Consider the duration of use and protection from the environment as appropriate. Those mustering will have only brought essential items, so thought should be given to having basic items available, such as drinking water. • Cover both evacuation and invacuation scenarios. • Provide sufficient flexibility that site users can be directed to specific muster points if required. • Use of muster points should be exercised/practised at least annually. • Maps showing the muster points must be displayed in the guard posts and SCR as a minimum. • All staff and regular users of the site should be aware of their corresponding muster point. • Site visitors must be made aware of the muster point they should use and if relevant, who their guide will be. • The OPERATOR (NEOM, PROPONENT OR OWNER) is responsible for ensuring a muster system is in place that allows the quick and effective accounting for all personnel on the site. SEC-SCH-002 NEOM Operational Site Security of Uncontrolled once printed NEOM – Operational Site Security GENERAL 1.0 PURPOSE The purpose of this document is to clearly define the responsibilities for the security of sites that have been brought into an operational state across the NEOM region. Operational refers to a site that is no longer under construction. This includes all aspects of site security, including: • Operating a secure site or building complex. • Controlling access and maintaining identity management. • Loss prevention, excluding people’s personal items that are not explicitly under the protection of the security provider. • Protection of staff, visitors and other personnel. • Physical protection of data. • Protection of the reputation of the site function, owner and NEOM. If the site is still under construction, or has not been formally handed over, then the security requirements under Schedule S – Construction should still be applied. 2.0 DEFINITIONS The document uses three distinct organisations: • NEOM – Refers to the client organisation, their divisions and their duties in relation to construction security. • OPERATOR (NEOM, PROPONENT OR OWNER) – Refers to the organisation or company that utilises the site for its intended primary function, or the management organisation for the site. This entity may be part of NEOM or a private organisation appointed by NEOM. • SECURITY SUPPLIER – Refers to the security provider employed by the OPERATOR (NEOM, PROPONENT OR OWNER), or in certain cases, NEOM, to provide security of the site and its associated activities. 3.0 APPLICABILITY This document, and its requirements, apply to all operational sites that are operated within NEOM, or on behalf of NEOM. The exception to this is only where NEOM Security Department (NEOM PUBLIC SAFETY - SECURITY have granted a waiver to this Standard because the site needs to operate at a higher security level. This may be the case with some sites in their end state operation, or where the site is designated Critical Regional Infrastructure (CRI). 4.0 SCOPE The scope of this document covers all operational sites and related activity undertaken by the OPERATOR (NEOM,PROPONENT OR OWNER). The document sets the minimum standards that are mandatory for the safe and secure operation of the site within NEOM. The aim of the mandatory minimum standards is to: • Set minimum standards to meet the general security threat situation in NEOM. • Provide a consistent approach to security within NEOM avoiding areas of increased vulnerability. SEC-SCH-002 NEOM Operational Site Security of Uncontrolled once printed NEOM – Operational Site Security 5.0 RESPONSIBILITIES NEOM are responsible for overall regional security and over-seeing the secure operation of sites within the NEOM region and also the regulation of private security within the NEOM region. The OPERATOR (NEOM, PROPONENT OR OWNER) is responsible to NEOM for the security of the operational site, their operations within NEOM and wider KSA related to the site, supply chain, administration and supporting corporate offices. This includes activities that may have a potentially negative effect on the reputation of NEOM. The OPERATOR (NEOM,PROPONENT OR OWNER) shall provide 24 hours-a-day, 7 days-a-week, 365 days-a-year (24/7/365) security to mitigate the identified security risks. Risk is a dynamic element, and the OPERATOR (NEOM,PROPONENT OR OWNER) should plan to review their related security risk: • On a periodic basis. • After an incident or near miss event. • If advised to do so by NEOM PUBLIC SAFETY - SECURITY • Making the necessary adjustments if the threat level has increased. Security measures should never be reduced beyond the relevant minimum level for the category of the site, as this is likely to reduce the deterrent effect achieved. To achieve the security requirements, the OPERATOR (NEOM, PROPONENT OR OWNER) must either provide a suitably qualified in-house professional security capability or employ a suitably qualified and resourced SECURITY SUPPLIER. [Referred to hereafter as the SECURITY SUPPLIER.] The SECURITY SUPPLIER must provide sufficient professional security personnel who are suitably trained and equipped, in conjunction with infrastructure provided at the operational site to meet the security requirements mandated by NEOM PUBLIC SAFETY - SECURITY / NEOC & NEOM EMERGENCY OPERATIONS CENTRE (NEOC) through the Operational Site Security Standard. SECURITY PROCESS 6.0 PROCESS The following process will be followed by all OPERATOR (NEOM,PROPONENT OR OWNER(S)) and their SECURITY SUPPLIERS to evidence their compliance with the mandatory security requirements of NEOM operational sites. Compliance will not be a ‘one-off’ event and NEOM PUBLIC SAFETY - SECURITY / NEOM EMERGENCY OPERATIONS CENTRE (NEOC) will audit the site security to ensure the minimum requirements are being met. SEC-SCH-002 NEOM Operational Site Security of Uncontrolled once printed NEOM – Operational Site Security 6.1 Site Suitability Assessment The Site Suitability Assessment (SSA) is undertaken to confirm that adequate security measures will be in place once the operational security overlay is applied. It should review the infrastructure, which should have been designed to meet the requirements for security and safety at the site, and it is therefore expected that minimal to no changes will be required. This form of a familiarisation visit will help both OPERATOR (NEOM,PROPONENT OR OWNER) and SECURITY SUPPLIER develop their Security Management Plan and Site Security Instructions, and identify those elements of non-fixed security infrastructure and resourcing to be provided under their contract. This may include radio systems, mobile duress alarms, search mirrors etc. A short report should be produced following the visit and submitted to NEOM PUBLIC SAFETY - SECURITY / NEOC & NEOM EMERGENCY OPERATIONS CENTRE (NEOC) for review and discussion. 7.0 SITE CATEGORISATION Every site within NEOM has been categorised using pre-defined criteria to establish the security risk level to the site and a corresponding Security Tier Level (STL). The STL sets the minimum or baseline security infrastructure standards that must be incorporated into the design of the site to meet the assessed threat in combination with: • An Operational Security Overlay: A Concept of Security Operations will be provided based upon the site design to provide an outline of the operational planning and activities envisioned for the site. The OPERATOR (NEOM, PROPONENT OR OWNER) is responsible for developing this information into the operational security employer requirements on which the contract with the SECURITY SUPPLIER will be based. • Site Security Procedures and Instructions: The OPERATOR (NEOM, PROPONENT OR OWNER) and SECURITY SUPPLIER are responsible for developing the correct level of procedures and instructions for the site, and these will form the basis of the Security Management Plan (Section 8) and the Site Security Instructions (Section 9). It is essential that the security infrastructure is operated and maintained correctly so that it has the desired security effect. Guidance around this is provided in Section 11 – Site Security Infrastructure and Section 12 – Identity Management and Access Control. 8.0 SECURITY MANAGEMENT PLAN The Security Management Plan (SMP) is the responsibility of the OPERATOR (NEOM,PROPONENT OR OWNER). The SMP should be produced a minimum of 12 weeks prior to the site moving to an operational status. The SMP provides a description of how the OPERATOR (NEOM,PROPONENT OR OWNER) will meet its security responsibilities. The minimum requirements of the SMP are detailed in Appendix A. The SMP shall be submitted to NEOM PUBLIC SAFETY - SECURITY / NEOC & NEOM EMERGENCY OPERATIONS CENTRE (NEOC) as evidence of adequate security planning having been Rev No: 0. SEC-SCH-002 NEOM Operational Site Security of Uncontrolled once printed NEOM – Operational Site Security undertaken. This includes the completion of the SMP Compliance Checklist, which is included at Appendix B to this document and the Security Overlays in Appendix C. As the SMP is the OPERATOR (NEOM,PROPONENT OR OWNER)’s responsibility, the Site Security Manager shall be a member of the OPERATOR (NEOM,PROPONENT OR OWNER)’s employed staff to ensure that the SMP is correctly interpreted and applied to the site. The SMP should evidence the capabilities of the site security infrastructure to allow the SMP to be further developed in sufficient detail with an intimate understanding of the site. To do this, a series of security overlays shall be prepared during the SMP stage. The required minimum overlays are as follows: • Privacy Zoning. • Access Control Overlay and Control Lines. • Dynamic Lockdown Procedure. • Surveillance Overlay Trace. • Intruder Detection Zones. • Search Difficulty Trace. • Evacuation and Invacuation Routes. • Emergency Red Routes. • Muster points. • Incident Control Points, Media Holding Area and Incident Vehicle Control Points. The overlays should be used operationally and incorporated into Security Control Room information and the information used during security activity and incidents. Examples are provided in Appendix C. It should be noted that the SMP is an auditable document. 9.0 SITE SECURITY INSTRUCTION The Site Security Instruction (SSI) is the responsibility of the SECURITY SUPPLIER, to meet the requirements of the OPERATOR (NEOM,PROPONENT OR OWNER)’s SMP. The SSI defines the procedures and assignment instructions that the SECURITY SUPPLIER will undertake on behalf of the OPERATOR (NEOM,PROPONENT OR OWNER) to achieve a safe and secure operational site. An SSI is required for all operational sites regardless of size and complexity. The fully completed SSI must be submitted a minimum of 4 weeks prior to any site being occupied. The minimum requirements of the SSI are detailed in Appendix D. The SSI Compliance Checklist is included at Appendix E. It should be noted that the SSI and its associated contents are auditable documents. Rev No: 0. SEC-SCH-002 NEOM Operational Site Security of Uncontrolled once printed NEOM – Operational Site Security 10.0 REPORTING REQUIREMENTS NEOM PUBLIC SAFETY - SECURITY / NEOC & NEOM EMERGENCY OPERATIONS CENTRE (NEOC) expects that the OPERATOR (NEOM,PROPONENT OR OWNER) and SECURITY SUPPLIER are responsible for the day-to-day application of security at the site under the leadership of the Site Security Manager. However, it is beneficial for certain events, occurrences and incidents to be reported to NEOM PUBLIC SAFETY - SECURITY / NEOC & NEOM EMERGENCY OPERATIONS CENTRE (NEOC). Therefore, the reporting requirements to NEOM PUBLIC SAFETY - SECURITY / NEOC & NEOM EMERGENCY OPERATIONS CENTRE (NEOC) are for the following three categories: • Management Information. • Information of Suspicious Nature. • Reportable Incidents. Report and Log formats have been standardised to keep consistency of reporting and reference the same across all operational sites. These can be found at Appendix F. 10.1 Management Information The OPERATOR (NEOM,PROPONENT OR OWNER), through the Site Security Manager, is responsible for ensuring the following management information is provided to the OPERATOR (NEOM,PROPONENT OR OWNER) and NEOM PUBLIC SAFETY - SECURITY / NEOC & NEOM EMERGENCY OPERATIONS CENTRE (NEOC), as indicated: Daily: • Reportable Incidents as defined in sub-section 11.3. A Nil Incidents to Report is not required and it will be assumed the absence of a report indicates this. • A Security Daily Activity Log shall be maintained as a complete diary of security activity, events and incidents on the site. These logs must be archived once full for a minimum period of two full calendar years, or longer if specified by local Police regulations, from the last dated entry. Weekly: • Dropped Security Shifts indicating the manpower shortfall and over what periods. • Planned duties/checks that did not occur in the week and the remedial plan to rectify. • Collated ‘Suspicious Activity’ Report. • Complaints registered against security staff, regardless of the outcome. • Occurrences that involve an external agency or government department. Monthly: • Review of site security including Site Security Manager and OPERATOR (NEOM,PROPONENT OR OWNER) management comments. • Incident data for the preceding month. See report formats included at Appendix F. Rev No: 0. This information will be assessed by the Site Security Manager and any appropriate investigation will be undertaken. Posters, computer banners and other highly viewed media should contain the NEOC number and details around caller confidentiality. A sample poster format is provided below. A collated report must be produced on a weekly basis that lists all reports of suspicious activity so that this can be reviewed for patterns and indicators of other potential occurrences by the Site Security Manager. NEOM Schedule S - Operations_LINK As a minimum, the following should be reported daily, or immediately dependent upon severity: • Injuries or fatalities. • Security incidents that will affect the normal use of the site. • Arrests or events that have involved outside organisations. • Security breaches. • Major security incidents, including any event that could lead to future media reporting. • Unusual public or media presence or activity. All of the above Reportable Incidents must use the report format included at Attachment 1 to this document. 11.0 SITE SECURITY INFRASTRUCTURE The site has been designed and constructed with site security infrastructure based upon the STL assigned to the site. It is imperative that this infrastructure is used effectively and that it is maintained to the highest standard to deliver its required security effect. The following sub- sections define activities that are mandatory for the types of infrastructure and the OPERATOR (NEOM,PROPONENT OR OWNER) and SECURITY SUPPLIER must ensure these are included in the relevant sections of the SMP and SSI. These activities will be audited. 11.1 Perimeter Fence, Wall or Boundary Barriers The site perimeter for any site is a vital barrier to entry, or important demarcation line for the rules and regulations of the site to be enforced. Therefore, there are activities that must be completed by the SECURITY SUPPLIER to ensure the correct level of security is maintained. 11.1.1 Physically Barriered Perimeters The following requirements to maintain security of the site shall be met: • During patrols security staff will ensure that sections of the perimeter are visually inspected for: o Damage to the fabric of the barrier. o Signs of climbing of the barrier from outside or inside. o Ensuring that climbing aids are not left against the barrier or with a horizontal distance of 2.0m of the barrier on either side. o Ensuring vehicles are not being parked against the barrier. SEC-SCH-002 NEOM Operational Site Security of Uncontrolled once printed NEOM – Operational Site Security o Any signage is still securely attached and has not become unreadable. o Any build up of litter should be reported to facilities management. o Any cover from view screens are still in place. • Attention should be made to ensure that spaces below any barrier are not becoming increased either purposefully or through weather erosion. Where this is occurring, this should be reported for maintenance and repair. • The patrol planning should take into account perimeter checks and also ensure over a weekly period that all areas of the perimeter are visited at least once physically. • Patrol patterns should not be pattern setting. • Observation should be made to identify areas of the perimeter where increased activity has taken place. This should be reported and placed onto the Security Control Room ‘Area-Watchlist’. • Checks should be completed at different times of the day, including dark hours and weekends. • If a breach in the barrier is discovered it should be reported immediately and security staff should remain at the breach until effective repairs have been completed, where a secure perimeter has been installed. • Patrols should assess lighting at the perimeter and report any damaged or partially operating lighting to facilities management for maintenance and repair. 11.1.2 Non-Physically Barriered Perimeters The following requirements to maintain security of the site shall be met: • Patrols should be tasked along the perimeter line of the site and pay particular attention to transition points on and off the site. • Patrols should check that any signage at the perimeter is secure and has not become unreadable or defaced. • Particular attention should be paid to areas where evidence of entry or exit has occurred that is not along a desired movement corridor. This should be reported to the SCR and placed upon the Security Control Room ‘Area Watchlist’. • Patrols should look for acts of anti-social behaviour, gatherings etc that will affect the reputation of the site. Where this is occurring then this should be discussed with the Site Security Manager to plan a long-term approach to prevention. • Patrols should assess lighting at the perimeter and report any damaged or partially operating lighting to facilities management for maintenance and repair. 11.2 Video Surveillance System To support the physical site perimeter and operational overlay, video cameras may have been installed to provide coverage of the perimeter line and access points into the site. It is assumed that each site will have a dedicated location within either the Guard Post or a dedicated Security Control Room to pro-actively manage the camera coverage. Advice and requirements for VSS/CCTV please contact NEOM Public Safety - Security Director for Command and Control prior to your RFP procurement request. The Visual Surveillance System (VSS/CCTV) should be used to: • Provide strong situational awareness across the site to support operational security. • Provide a verification method for any intrusion alarms. OPERATOR (NEOM, Proponent or Owner(s)) need to be fully trained and compliant with any local regulations. The system must be reviewed regularly to ensure cameras are providing the images and image quality expected of the system. The SECURITY SUPPLIER is expected in conjunction with the OPERATOR (NEOM,PROPONENT OR OWNER) to ensure regular cleaning is undertaken in-line with any maintenance agreement. 11.3 Security Lighting and other External Illumination All security lighting and external lighting that aids safety and security should be inspected on a regular basis to ensure it is functional, undamaged and providing the required illumination. Where this is not the case, this should be reported to facilities management for maintenance and repair. Security staff should ensure that torches, hand-held or temporary illumination devices are serviceable and fully charged prior to dark hours shifts so that sufficient resilience and redundancy is present should a failure in fixed illumination occur. This is especially important at entry/exit points on the site. Dirty lights should be reported to facilities management for maintenance. Patrols must operate in safe lighting conditions but beyond strongly lit areas to be able to provide observation of less well lit areas. Night-time patrol planning should take account of this requirement to ensure that all areas of the site are adequately patrolled. 11.4 Security Guard Posts Security Guard Posts will be fixed infrastructure at the main ingress / egress point(s), to monitor and control movement onto and off site. These locations will serve as the Vehicle Access Control Points and Pedestrian Access Control Points for the site and are therefore vital to maintaining the required security level for the site. The Security Guard Posts are to be maintained and operated to the highest standards as these form the first impression that users and visitors of the site form about the professionalism and effectiveness of both site security, but also the wider site operations standard. A key element of the perception of the Security Guard Post will be formed on the following factors: • Cleanliness and neatness of the area. Rev No: 0. SEC-SCH-002 NEOM Operational Site Security of Uncontrolled once printed NEOM – Operational Site Security • Proactive, friendly and helpful interaction with security staff. • Robust, but polite removal of unauthorised people and vehicles. • Serviceability of all infrastructure in the area, especially elements such as shade cover, lighting etc that are very visual elements. • Timely processing of visitors to the right location with the right information and guidance. Staff attitude is key, and a concierge approach should be adopted. Site entry/exit procedures and the Security Guard Posts will be a principal focus of audits and also should correspondingly serve as an important measure of user satisfaction with security services. 11.5 Radio and Cellular Security Communications The SECURITY SUPPLIER will be responsible for the operation and maintenance of a site wide radio system for security personnel. The radio system must provide full coverage of the site, but is not required for communication to NEOM PUBLIC SAFETY - SECURITY / NEOC & NEOM EMERGENCY OPERATIONS CENTRE (NEOC). It is however, expected that the SECURITY SUPPLIER will also operate and maintain cellular phones for contact beyond the site boundaries. Security personnel should be encouraged to talk with site users and visitors, and this will have a positive effect on how the role of security is viewed on the site.
